How to override destroy method keeping the callbacks

May 02
2011

While working on a project, we were required to override the destroy method in order to create a soft delete method, in other words to change the active state of the object to deleted instead of deleting it from the database.

That was no problem at all, but, issues came when we needed this method to use callbacks in order for the counter caches to work properly.

In Rails 2 you can override the destroy method without affecting callbacks by overriding the method destroy_without_callbacks

  def destroy_without_callbacks
    unless new_record?
      # your code here
    end
    freeze
  end

But in Rails 3 things have changed and the previous methods won't work. So, after some research, we found out that you can call the method callbacks with the run_callbacks method from ActiveSupport

    def destroy
      run_callbacks :destroy do
        # your code here
      end
    end

In this case we use it for the destroy method, but you can use it for any method you override and need their callbacks. If you don't specify any callbacks, all callbacks will be called.

You can find more info here

Hope this may help you in your overriding tasks.
